1528703264_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5.body: I believe that *optional* content filtering is something that would be of benefit to ZeroNet.  I also believe that a Web of Trust model could be leveraged to provide a wealth of options to ZeroNet, one of which being optional content filtering.

> [thunder33345](#comment_3_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5FMX5K): yep as soon as "optional" became mandatory it's no longer called content filter but censorship

Correct.  Fortunately on ZeroNet it doesn't matter if someone creates something you dislike.  Even filtering that is perceived as "mandatory".  Just don't use that system or those zites.  Free speech advocates like yourself can and will make a place for the speech they enjoy and ZeroNet is resilient enough to support multiple mutually-exclusive opinions on filtering.

With a WoT (web of trust) multiple mutually exclusive opinions on content and users can exist simultaneously and users can opt to see only content trusted by people they trust or not.  (potentially)

Potentially the WoT might be able to have users flag zites with community generated tags (like Steam does) and regardless of whether users spam/flood the WoT, the content can still be useful based on how much users trust or distrust the individuals.

Win/win IMO.

If you're here for puppies and hate kittens, a WoT could help you avoid seeing kittens and help you see more puppies.

It could also help people determine if they want to agree to an online transaction with someone they've never had interaction with.

It could also really help with search, and zites for search could trust and or distrust users to flag zites appropriately.  A search zite could spring up that is weighted towards puppies, and another could spring up that is weighted towards kittens.  If we can work together and accurately label content it would be of benefit to everyone regardless of our stances on the content in question.

It could help users avoid what they deem as "garbage" content by whichever metrics they choose to be "garbage".  I don't really see a drawback to it other than:

* A WoT zite might not be trusted, so having protocol that enables users to host their own trust dbs adhering to a specific format might be handy.  The WoT site should be FOSS and/or able to be cloned, so that if there is a trust issue with the zite owner, others can spring up without effort and "merger" (or something) the end user trust dbs.

* It would have to be implemented and that takes time and effort.

Thoughts?

How else could ZeroNet benefit from a FOSS, decentralized, distributed, clonable, WoT?

> [thunder33345](#comment_4_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5FMX5K):  it's still kinda up to site to allow/enable WOT support

I'm thinking, potentially wrongly, that it could be done independent of support by the zites and users being trusted or untrusted.

It would be nice if in my user's trust db (hosted on my personal zite or something) could include a trust value for "Unlimit Talk"'s URL of http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HMLvnRWViMnuvZc5LK4Dm86sZNcSH1jdh

That zite wouldn't need anything special in order for me to trust or distrust it.  It should be able to be done in a manner that allows users the freedom to "thumbs up" or "thumbs down" content without the consent of the content creator.  But it should also not be a plurality, if possible.  There could (and maybe I'm just too head-in-the-clouds here), but there could be a way for a user to say that "Unlimit Talk" is both flagged by me in my personally controlled db, as both "puppies" as well as "kittens" and "apples" but not "oranges", etc.

If it relies on specific zite support, it will not be a useful curation tool.

Addendum to last post:

A WoT zite that was FOSS could act as a content curation gateway and read user's trust db.  This wouldn't need any changes to how ZeroNet works since everything would be zites.  No mandatory anything.

If the WoT zite that was the defacto standard became untrusted by the userbase, another one adhering to the same db standard could be cloned.

Oh, you mean embedding it in the curation zite?  The problem there, IMO, is that if the curation zite is not to be trusted, then we can't trust the user data stored there.  Users should store their own data independently of the curation gateway.  That should allow us to move from an untrusted WoT zite to a trusted one without losing the community curation data, and still being able to trust that our trust level of their trust data is accurate.

Or are you suggesting that the zite that is being trusted/untrusted host the db that says they are trusted or not?  If a zite is untrusted would you really trust it enough to say that it was untrusted?  Users really should be the ones in control of their own trust DBs, not zites.

That makes sense.  What about the event where the zite owner is intentionally a jerk, and deletes the trust dbs?  Shouldn't they be controlled by the users to prevent this?
